facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 101 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 101 of 1969.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 16, 1969 of the Rajasthan High Court in S. B. Criminal Appeal No. 558 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 16, 1969 of the Rajasthan High Court in S. B. Criminal Appeal No. 558 of 1966.

facts.text: The accused was initially charged on three counts: under section 5(2) read with section 5(1)(c) of the Prevention of Corruption Act 1947, under section 409 IPC, and under section 477A IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Jaganmohan Reddy, J. This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the Rajasthan High Court. The accused was initially charged on three companynts, firstly, under section 5 2  read with section 5 1  c  of the Prevention of Corruption Act 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act , secondly, under section 409, I.P.C., and thirdly, under section 477A, I.P.C.

facts.text: On 15-1-1964 another Special Judge charged him on two counts: under section 5(2) read with section 5(1)(c) and section 5(2) read with section 5(1)(d) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on 15-1-1964 another Special Judge charged him on two companynts, namely, under section 5  2  read with section 5   1   c  and section 5  2  read with section 5  1   w  of the Act.

facts.text: The appellant was convicted under section 409 IPC and section 5(2) read with section 5(1)(c) and (d) of the Act and sentenced to 18 months RI and fine of Rs. 250/- on each, to run concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: After the trial, the appellant was, however, companyvicted under section 409, I.P.C. and section 5 2  read with section 5 1  c  and  d  of the Act and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment of 18 months and a fine of Rs. 250/- under-section 409, I.P.C. and 18 months rigorous imprisonment, and a fine of Rs. 250/- under section 5 2  read with sections 5 1  c  and 5 1  d  of the Act. The sentences on both these companynts were, directed to run companycurrently.

facts.text: The High Court confirmed the conviction and sentence under section 409 IPC and section 5(2) r/w 5(1)(c), reduced fine to Rs. 150/- each, and did not record conviction under 5(1)(d).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, thought that the Special Judge had number recorded any companyviction under section 5 1  d  of the Act and in that view companyfirmed the companyviction and sentence of the appellant of 18 months rigorous imprisonment on each of the companynts, namely, under section 409, I.P.C. and section 5 2  read with section 5 1  c  of the Act, but reduced the fine for each of the offences from Rs. 250/- to Rs. 150/-.

facts.text: The appellant was employed as a Traffic Assistant in the Indian Airlines Corporation office at Jaipur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was employed as a Traffic Assistant in the Indain Airlines Corporations office at Jaipur and his duty was to make reservations of the passengers intending to go by air and issue tickets.

facts.text: His duty was to make reservations for passengers and issue tickets.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was employed as a Traffic Assistant in the Indain Airlines Corporations office at Jaipur and his duty was to make reservations of the passengers intending to go by air and issue tickets.

facts.text: When quota of seats allotted to Jaipur is full, intending travellers pay trunk telephone charges to obtain release of seats from other centers.

anchor.surface_text: As it happens, when the quota of seats allotted to Jaipur is full, intending travellers who request for accommodation would be required to pay trunk telephone charges for enabling the Airlines Corporation to obtain release of seats from quotas allotted to other centers.

facts.text: The appellant was in charge of these arrangements between 16-2-62 and 30-8-62.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was incharge of these arrangements between 16-2-62 and 30-8- 62, companylected Rs. 184.90 towards trunk telephone charges but actually deposited with the Airlines Corporation a sum of Rs. 44.91 and misappropriated the balance of Rs. 139.99.

facts.text: Appellant collected Rs. 184.90 towards trunk telephone charges but deposited only Rs. 44.91, misappropriating Rs. 139.99.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was incharge of these arrangements between 16-2-62 and 30-8- 62, companylected Rs. 184.90 towards trunk telephone charges but actually deposited with the Airlines Corporation a sum of Rs. 44.91 and misappropriated the balance of Rs. 139.99.

facts.text: Modus operandi: demanded higher amount for trunk calls than actual, issued receipt for higher amount, altered counter-foil to actual, deposited actual.

anchor.surface_text: The modus operendi followed by him, it is alleged, was that he would demand a higher amount for Trunk Call charges than were likely to be incurred and he would issue a companyrect receipt for those amounts on behalf of the Airlines Corporation but after making the trunk call, he would alter the companynter-foil with the actual amount of trunk call charges.

facts.text: Exhibit 40 is a receipt dated 30-8-62 for Rs. 23.40 from M/s. M Travels for trunk call charges to Udaipur and AMD.

anchor.surface_text: A typical sample of the receipts given by him on behalf of the Airlines Corporation is Exhibit 40 which is as follows INDIAN AIRLINES CORPORATION NEW DELHI. No. 354577 Station Jaipur. Date 30-8-62. Received with thanks from M s. M Travels, Jaipur sum of Rupees Twenty three and forty nP, being the amount T Call charges to Udaipur and AMD for re-lease of seat.

facts.text: On 31-8-62, M.D. Singh of Mercury Travel Agency complained to B.S. Gupta that appellant collected Rs. 23.40 but made no call and no seat allotted.

anchor.surface_text: On 31-8-62, one M.D. Singh ofthe Mercury Travel Agency, Jaipur companyplained to B.S. Gupta, Incharge of the Office of the Indian Airlines Corporation at Jaipur that the appellant had companylected Rs. 23.40 for proposed trunk call charges from the Agency but made numbercall and numberseat was allotted to the passenger of the Mercury Travel Agency even though one was available and that seat was given by B. S. Gupta to someone else.

facts.text: B.S. Gupta questioned the appellant, who confessed to collecting the amount but not making the call, and immediately resigned.

anchor.surface_text: B. S. Gupta questioned the appellant who then made a companyfession of his having companylected the amount but number having made a call. After-making this companyfession he immediately resigned his job.

facts.text: Area Manager conducted preliminary inquiry and lodged First Information Report.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary inquiry was companyducted by the Area Manager who thereafter lodged the First Information Report.

facts.text: The accused denied having collected the amounts or issued the receipts and stated that whatever amounts collected were paid in the office everyday.

anchor.surface_text: The accused denied having companylected the amounts or of having issued the receipts and further stated that whatever amounts were companylected by him were paid in the office of the Airlines everyday.

facts.text: Both courts found that the appellant made trunk calls, received charges, gave receipts in his handwriting, and realized total Rs. 185/- entrusted to him as public servant.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Courts found on the evidence that the appellant used to make trunk calls whenever he was on duty from the Indian Airlines Corporation office at Jaipur for the release of seats and that he would call for and receive trunk call charges from intending passengers. It was further held proved that the appellant gave receipts Exhibited in the case which were in his own hand-writing and signed by him and that it was he who realised the total sum of Rs. 185/- which was entrusted to him and over which he, had a dominion in his capacity as a public servant.

facts.text: High Court did not confirm conviction under section 5(2) r/w 5(1)(d), no appeal by State.

anchor.surface_text: We have already pointed out that the High Court did number companyfirm the companyviction of the appellant under section 5 2  read with section 5 1  d  on the assumption that the-said Special Judge had number companyvicted the accused for that offence, and since there is numberappeal by the State against this part of the judgment, the companytention on behalf of the State that he was companyvicted under section 5 1  d  has numbermerits and cannot be sustained.

facts.text: Appellant urged benefit of Probation of Offenders Act before High Court, rejected due to conviction under s.409 IPC punishable with life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was urged before the High Court that as the appellant had to fare a trial extending over more than 3 years incurring enormous expenses for companying to and from Chandigarh where he was practicing law and was also in Jail for some time, the benefit of the Probation of Offenders Act should be given to him This companytention was rejected because the provisions of that Art were inapplicable in view of his companyviction under section 409, I.P.C.

facts.text: M.U. Menon (PW6) testified about practice: on 16-2-1962, directed to arrange tickets, IAC asked for Rs.410.50 including Rs.26.50 trunk charges.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, the practice which was being followed by the Jaipur office of the Indian Airlines Corporation is spoken to by M. U. Menon, P.W. 6, who was a Personal Assistant to the General Manager of the National Engineering Industries Ltd., Jaipur. He says that on 16-2-1962 his General Manager had directed him to issue instructions to the accounts branch for arranging for flight tickets by air for Delhi.

facts.text: Ganesh Singh (PW3) testified that IAC asked for trunk call charges along with ticket amounts, paid and received receipt.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly Ganesh Singh, P.W. 3 who is working for the National Engineering Indus his people companytacted Indian Airlines tries Ltd., Jaipur said that when Corporation on telephone and enquired about the fare etc. they would ask for trunk call charges along with the amount for tickets.

facts.text: Amounts for trunk call charges were paid to Indian Airlines Corporation, receipts given on its behalf, entrusting appellant with the amount.

anchor.surface_text: The amount was number paid by passengers to the accused as such but to the Indian Airline.,, Corporation and as soon as the receipt for the amount actually received from the passengers was given by the accused on behalf of the Corporation, he was entrusted with that amount.

issues.text: Whether the appellant was convicted under section 5(2) read with section 5(1)(d) of the Act and whether that conviction can be sustained in the absence of an appeal by the State

anchor.surface_text: We have already pointed out that the High Court did not confirm the conviction of the appellant under section 5 2  read with section 5 1  d on the assumption that the-said Special Judge had not convicted the accused for that offence, and since there is no appeal by the State against this part of the judgment, the contention on behalf of the State that he was convicted under section 5 1  d has no merits and cannot be sustained.

issues.text: Whether the appellant is entitled to the benefit of the Probation of Offenders Act

anchor.surface_text: the benefit of the Probation of Offenders Act should be given to him This contention was rejected because the provisions of that Act were inapplicable in view of his conviction under section 409, I.P.C. As the offence of criminal breach of trust under section 409, I.P.C. is punishable with imprisonment for life, the High Court, in our view, was right because the provisions of section 4 are only applicable to a case of a person found guilty

issues.text: Whether there was entrustment of the amounts collected towards trunk telephone charges to the appellant in his capacity as public servant so as to constitute criminal misconduct under section 5(2) read with section 5(1)(c) of the Prevention of Corruption Act and criminal breach of trust under section 409 IPC

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it is submitted by the learned Advocate that the prosecution case as disclosed by the evidence was that the appellant had collected excess charges from the passengers representing them to be the actual charges for trunk calls and not that any excess over the actual charges would be returned to them. In view of this evidence, the appellant could not be convicted either under section 5 2  read with section 5 1  c  of the Act or under section 409, I.P.C. because the important ingredient which is entrustment of the amounts is absent.

arguments.claim: No entrustment of amounts as required for conviction under s.5(2) r/w 5(1)(c) PCA or s.409 IPC because appellant collected excess charges by representing as actual trunk call charges, not to be returned, obtained by cheating.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it is submitted by the learned Advocate that the prosecution case as disclosed by the evidence was that the appellant had collected excess charges from the passengers representing them to be the actual charges for trunk calls and not that any excess over the actual charges would be returned to them. In view of this evidence, the appellant could not be convicted either under section 5 2  read with section 5 1  c  of the Act or under section 409, I.P.C. because the important ingredient which is entrustment of the amounts is absent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ection 409, I.P.C. is punishable with imprisonment for life, the High Court, in our view, was right because the provisions of section 4 are only appli

arguments.court_reasoning: Entrustment under s.405 IPC wide ('in any manner'); even if by cheating/false pretense, if received in official capacity for specific purpose/benefiting Corporation, constitutes entrustment; supported by precedents and evidence.

arguments.claim: Entrustment requires money to be lawfully handed over; here obtained by cheating so no entrustment for s.409 IPC or s.5(1)(c) PCA.

anchor.surface_text: In order that any amount can be said to be entrusted it should be lawfully made over, but in this case the appellant obtained the amount by cheating and by the commission of an offence. If there was no entrustment of the moneys to the appellant, he could not be convicted either under section 409 or under section 5 2  read with 5 1  c  of the Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ent as he companyld number be a trustee of that money on behalf of the cultivators, from whom he realised it because when they banded over the money t

arguments.court_reasoning: s.405 does not require 'lawful'; 'in any manner entrusted' significant; possession for specific purpose suffices.

arguments.claim: Surendra Pal Singh v. State supports no entrustment for excess collected/misappropriated by public servant as no trusteeship for payers or government.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this contention reliance has been placed on Surendra Pal Singh v. The State 1 , where a Bench of the Allahabad High Court held that the amounts collected from cultivators by the Canal Amin in excess of the amount actually due from them and misappropriated by him, did not amount to an entrustment as he could not be a trustee of that money on behalf of the cultivators, from whom he realised it because when they handed over the money to the accused, they purported to surrender all their rights in that money, not could it be said that this money had become the property of the Government at any stage for him to be considered a trustee on its behalf.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: read with section 5 1  c  of the Act or under section 409, I.P.C. because the important ingredient which is entrustment of the amounts is absent. In

arguments.court_reasoning: Disapproved in State v. Dahyalal Dalpatram (Bombay HC), view agreed by Rajasthan HC.

arguments.claim: Dahyalal case distinguishable: there was definite direction to collect specific amount lawfully due, unlike here.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate sought to distinguish this case on the ground that in the Bombay case there was a definite direction to collect a specific amount and when that amount was collected there was entrustment of that money which was lawfully collected, as such the accused was rightly convicted. It was further contended that if looked at from the point of view of the passengers from whom trunk call charges were collected, they had not entrusted money to the accused because they had parted with the proprietary rights thereon and if viewed from the point of view of the Airlines Corporation, the money collected did not become the property of the Corporation and consequently there was no entrustment of it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a Pal Singh v. The State 1 , where a Bench of the Allahabad High Court held that the amounts companylected from cultivators by the Canal Amin in exces

arguments.court_reasoning: Entrustment wide regardless of direction or lawfulness; applies to money collected on behalf of Corporation.

arguments.claim: s.405 IPC entrustment is wide: 'in any manner entrusted'; includes possession for specific purpose even if not property of entruster; agent misappropriating guilty.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that before a public servant can be convicted of an offence under section 5 1  c  or under section 409, I.P.C. the property which is said to, have been misappropriated must be entrusted to him. Section 405 merely provides, whoever being in any manner entrusted with property or with any dominion over the property, as the first ingredient of the criminal breach of trust. The words in any manner in the context are significant. The section does not provide that the entrustment of property should be by someone or the amount received must be the property of the person on whose behalf it is received.

arguments.claim: Precedents support entrustment even for money received by false pretense/cheating if for master's benefit/specific purpose: Ram Sounder Poddar, Re Ramappa, Venkata Raghunatha Sastri, Crown v. McIver.

anchor.surface_text: As long as the accused is given possession of property for a specific purpose or to, deal with it in a particular manner, the ownership being in some person other than the accused, he can be said to be entrusted with that property to be applied in accordance with the terms of entrustment and for the benefit of the owner. The expression entrusted in section 409 is used in a wide sense and includes all cases in which property is voluntarily handed over for a specific purpose and is dishonestly disposed of contrary to the terms on which possession has been handed over.

arguments.claim: Evidence of witnesses (PW6 M.U. Menon, PW3 Ganesh Singh) proves practice: trunk charges demanded/paid/receipted on behalf of IAC, entrusting accused.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, the practice which was being followed by the Jaipur office of the Indian Airlines Corporation is spoken to by M. U. Menon, P.W. 6, who was a Personal Assistant to the General Manager of the National Engineering Industries Ltd., Jaipur. He says that on 16-2-1962 his General Manager had directed him to issue instructions to the accounts branch for arranging for flight tickets by air for Delhi.

arguments.claim: Amounts paid to Indian Airlines Corporation via accused's receipt on its behalf constitutes entrustment to accused as public servant; subsequent falsification/misappropriation = criminal breach of trust under s.409 IPC.

holdings.text: The contention on behalf of the State that he was convicted under section 5(2) read with section 5(1)(d) has no merits and cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: the companytention on behalf of the State that he was companyvicted under section 5 1  d has numbermerits and cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court did not confirm conviction under 5(1)(d) assuming Special Judge did not record it; no appeal filed by State against that part of judgment.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in rejecting benefit of Probation of Offenders Act as provisions of section 4 inapplicable to offences punishable with life imprisonment and section 18 excludes offences under section 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court, in our view, was right because the provisions of section 4 are only applicable to a case of a person found guilty of having companymitted an offence number punishable with death or imprisonment for life. Apart from this reasoning, section 18 of the Probation of Offenders Act makes, the provisions of that Act inapplicable

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.409 IPC punishable with life imprisonment excludes s.4 POA; s.18 POA explicitly excludes PCA s.5(2).

holdings.text: The appellant was entrusted with trunk call charges collected on behalf of Indian Airlines Corporation upon issuing receipts, and his misappropriation constitutes criminal breach of trust under section 409 IPC and criminal misconduct under section 5(2) read with 5(1)(c) of Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: The amount was number paid by passengers to the accused as such but to the Indian Airline.,, Corporation and as soon as the receipt for the amount actually received from the passengers was given by the accused on behalf of the Corporation, he was entrusted with that amount. His subsequent companyduct in falsifying the companynter-foils and fraudulently misappropriating the amounts would make him guilty of criminal breach of trust punishable under section 409, I.P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entrustment under s.405 IPC broad ('in any manner'); money paid to Corporation via official receipt creates dominion for specific purpose; supported by witness evidence on practice and precedents like Dahyalal, Ramappa; rejects cheating precludes entrustment.

holdings.text: The expression 'entrusted' in section 409 IPC and section 5(1)(c) PCA used in wide sense including property voluntarily handed over for specific purpose even if obtained by false pretense, so long as possession for master's benefit.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt that before a public servant can be companyvicted of an offence under section 5 1  c  or under section 409, I.P.C. the property which is said to, have been misappropriated must be entrusted to him. Section 405 merely provides, whoever being in any manner entrusted with property or with any dominion over the property, as the first ingredient of the criminal breach of trust. The words in any manner in the companytext are significant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'in any manner entrusted' in s.405; follows precedents (Ram Sounder Poddar, Re Ramappa, Venkata Raghunatha Sastri, Crown v. McIver) disapproving narrow views like Surendra Pal Singh.

precedents.citation: Surendra Pal Singh v. The State 1 A.I.R. 1957 All. 122

anchor.surface_text: In support of this contention reliance has been placed on Surendra Pal Singh v. The State 1 , where a Bench of the Allahabad High Court held that the amounts collected from cultivators by the Canal Amin in excess of the amount actually due from them and misappropriated by him, did number amount to an entrustment as he could not be a trustee of that money on behalf of the cultivators, from whom he realised it because when they banded over the money to the accused, they purported to surrender all their rights in that money, number could it be said that this money had become the property of the Government at any stage for him to be considered a trustee on its behalf.

precedents.case_name: Surendra Pal Singh v The State
precedents.cited_proposition: amounts collected from cultivators by the Canal Amin in excess of the amount actually due from them and misappropriated by him, did not amount to an entrustment as he could not be a trustee of that money

precedents.citation: The State v. Dahyalal Dalpatram 2 A.I.R. 1960 Bom. 53

anchor.surface_text: This decision was, however, disapproved in The State v. Dahyalal Dalpatram 2 , by a Bench of the Bombay High Court, a view with which the High Court agreed. In that case the accused who was employed as a Talati in the Revenue Department, was invested with the authority to collect land revenue and fines. He was ordered to recover from the land-holders who had defaulted in paying the moneys but having collected them, be did number pay them into the Government Treasury as required by the rules made under the Land Revenue Code. The accused was convicted under section 409, I.P.C. On the question that when the accused collected the amount as tax alleged to be due by the land-holder though the liability whereof could number be enforced according to law. could it be said that he was then entrusted with the money, the High Court after noticing that the Allahabad High Court appears to have taken the view that a public servant collecting the money claiming that it was, due to the State but which in fact was number due to the State, could number be regarded as entrusted with the money collected by him, held that that was number a necessary ingredient of section 405.

precedents.cited_proposition: public servant collecting money claiming due to State though not due, is entrusted with it; not necessary that it be lawfully due for entrustment under section 405
precedents.cited_holding: held that that was not a necessary ingredient of section 405

precedents.citation: In the matter of Ram Sounder Poddar Ors. 1 1878 2 al. L.R. 515

anchor.surface_text: of different High Courts in this country for nearly a century, a few of which alone need be examined. In the matter of Ram Sounder Poddar Ors.  1 , a Deputy Magistrate convicted the accused under section 406, I.P.C., an offence over which he had jurisdiction, instead of under section 409, i.p.c. which was cognizance only by the Court of Session. on revision the High Court held that the proceedings were contrary to law and the Deputy Magistrate was directed to commit the accused for trial by the Court of Session. It appears that the accused who were charged were Treasury employees. One of the accused  1  1878  2  al. L.R. 515.

precedents.cited_proposition: section 409 does number require the property in respect of which criminal breach of trust is committed, to be the property of Government, but only requires that it should be entrusted to a public servant in his capacity as such public servant

anchor.surface_text: In re Ramappa 1 , the accused who was the Superintendent of some Coffee Curing Works was convicted of criminal breach of trust by misappropriating a large sum of money made up of amounts which he had received from the Manager on the false pretense that they were required for paying coolies who garbled coffee. One of the arguments urged against the conviction was that the receipt of the money by false representation amounted to an offence of cheating and that the subsequent appropriation of it by the accused to his own use was number a criminal breach of trust as the criminal intent was present at the time of the receipt of the moneys from the Manager. Benson and Sundara Aiyar, J., while rejecting that argument, observed When the accused received the money he did so as a servant of the Company for the express purpose of using it for his masters benefit in a particular way. He was, therefore, entrusted with the money and his appropriating it to himself clearly amounts to criminal breach of trust.

precedents.cited_proposition: receipt of money by false representation does not preclude entrustment if received as servant for specific purpose; subsequent appropriation is criminal breach of trust
precedents.cited_holding: When the accused received the money he did so as a servant of the Company for the express purpose of using it for his masters benefit in a particular way. He was, therefore, entrusted with the money and his appropriating it to himself clearly amounts to criminal breach of trust.

anchor.surface_text: In Venkata Raghunatha Sastri 2 , Spencer, J., held that where a person who had pledged promissory notes with another as security for a loan dishonestly induced the latter to hand over the same to him by pretending that he required the same for collecting money from his creditors with the aid of which he would pay cash to the complainant, his act constituted an offence of cheating punishable under section 420, I.P.C. and that when he dishonestly disposed of the notes in violation of his contract with the pledgee to use the money collected in paying off his debt, there was both entrustment and dishonest misappropriation and that the conviction for the offence of criminal breach of trust under section 406, I.P.C. was legal.

precedents.cited_proposition: obtaining property by dishonest inducement constitutes cheating, but subsequent dishonest disposal constitutes also criminal breach of trust
precedents.cited_holding: there was both entrustment and dishonest misappropriation and that the conviction for the offence of criminal breach of trust under section 406, I.P.C. was legal

precedents.citation: The Crown Prosecutor v. McIver and K. S. Narasimhachari 3 69 M.L.J. 681

anchor.surface_text: Both these cases were referred to in The Crown Prosecutor v. McIver and K. S. Narasimhachari 3 . The facts in this case also were somewhat similar to those in Venkataraghunatha Sastris case 4   Madhavan Nair, J  as he then was  examined the meaning of the word entrusted in section 406 and rejected a similar contention as was urged in this case on behalf of the appellant that when the accused by deceiving the complainant fraudulently and  1   1911  22 M.L.J. 112.  3  69 M.L.J. 681.  2   1923  45 M.L.J. 133  4  45 M.L.J. 133. dishonestly induced him to part with the property in question, the offence of cheating was complete and that there is number room for further holding that the accused have committed criminal breach of trust also by their subsequent misappropriation of the property.

precedents.case_name: Crown Prosecutor v McIver and K S Narasimhachari
precedents.cited_proposition: when accused deceives to obtain property, offence of cheating complete, but subsequent misappropriation still constitutes criminal breach of trust
precedents.cited_holding: rejected ... that ... the offence of cheating was complete and that there is no room for further holding that the accused have committed criminal breach of trust also by their subsequent misappropriation of the property

anchor.surface_text: The amount was number paid by passengers to the accused as such but to the Indian Airline.,, Corporation and as soon as the receipt for the amount actually received from the passengers was given by the accused on behalf of the Corporation, he was entrusted with that amount. His subsequent companyduct in falsifying the companynter-foils and fraudulently misappropriating the amounts would make him guilty of criminal breach of trust punishable under section 409, I.P.C.
